texts.definition: Scenes that interrupt and contextualize an ongoing scene by presenting information relevant to the current situation.
markups: <style="Definition">Scenes that interrupt and contextualize an ongoing scene by presenting information relevant to the current situation.</style>

Live Action Roleplaying Games typically try to avoid have information given to players about the events without these being enacted. Contextualization is a technique that allows players to enact flashbacks or flashforwards that interrupt the current scene to present additional information about it.

The Black Box technique in Live Action Roleplaying Games is an archetypal example of Contextualization. The Make a Speech technique used in the LARP Joakim shows a public example of contextualization; when players initiate a speech to the absent former classmate Joakim the rule stipulate that the characters hear this speech but the players tell the other players a memory about how they mistreated him.

The prime design question regarding the use of <style="CurrentLink">Contextualization</style> is when the <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> the contextualization should be initialized. Other questions relate to if players can initiate the <style="CurrentLink">Contextualizations</style> or if only <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> or events begin them, if they should be flashbacks or "flashforwards", and if they should make use of other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Contextualization</style> is a <style="Link"><link="meta-techniques">Meta-Technique</link></style> using whole <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> as its format, thereby both creating <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> and modifying existing ones. It can easily break <style="Link"><link="temporal-consistency">Temporal Consistency</link></style> by having the <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> take place in the past or future of what is "currently" happening in a game instance.

The use of the pattern modifies players' possibility of <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> in that they can portray <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> at other times or even other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that are relevant to the narration.
